awd_titl_txt: VIERS the next 50 years:  rebuilding resilient research infrastructure at the Virgin Islands Environmental Resource Station (VIERS)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Virgin Islands Environmental Resource Station (VIERS) is located in the heart of the Virgin Islands National Park (VINP), owned by the University of the Virgin Islands (UVI) (located on St. Thomas). VIERS has a 50 year legacy of serving generations of scientifically literate citizens, educators, and researchers. Research at VIERS provides one of the longest running insights into the changes affecting Caribbean reefs. Of central importance in the legacy of VIERS is its unique location in a US National Park in the eastern Caribbean, and the novelty of a fully-protected watershed. These benefits have been recognized by NSF through ongoing support of coral reef research, including most recently, efforts to quantify hurricane effects through RAPID grants. VIERS provides critical access to science infrastructure for underrepresented groups (Caribbean islanders) through a significant HBCU (i.e., UVI). Specifically, these advantages accrue through: (a) the global benefits of ensuring the longevity of an historically important field station at a time when such facilities are critically needed, (b) sustaining the capacity to mentor and train the next generation of biologists through real-world natural history experiences, (c) supporting research of national importance to the US to manage coral resources in one of the only areas of coral reef with MPA status in US waters, and (d) provision of education, research, and training opportunities for US Caribbean islanders that are chronically under-represented in science and education.

Damage caused by two Category 5 hurricanes (Irma and Maria in 2017) severely impacted the capacity to conduct research and education in St. John, US Virgin Islands. Many cabins and related buildings were displaced, flooded through, and severed from electrical and plumbing infrastructure. A two-phased restoration plan has be developed. Phase 1, to be supported by this grant, will construct new visiting scientist housing and work space in a location directly adjacent to the laboratory building which survived the storms. Phase 2 will be to restore the cabins damaged by the hurricanes, rebuilding them and re-setting them on their foundations. The investment in Phase 1 will restore research activities as quickly as possible.  Once Phase 2 is complete and the damaged infrastructure is replaced, this new structure will represent an expansion over previous housing capacity, serving researchers that need 24-hour access to the marine environment. This will put VIERS on a renewed trajectory of grown into research on the ecology of coral reefs, forecasting the future, and training scientists for the 21st Century.  For more information on VIERS, visit http://www.islands.org/viers/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The University of the Virgin Islands, with funding from the National Science Foundation's Biological Field Stations and Marine Laboratories within the directorate for Biological Sciences, completed significant renovations of the Virgin Islands Environmental Resource Station (VIERS) laboratory on Lameshur Bay, St John US Virgin Islands.   Originally established as a base camp in 1966 to study the effects of living in a confined underwater habitat during the Tektite projects, the VIERS camp and laboratory has a fifty-year history of scientific success as a remote field station and marine laboratory. Now operated by the University of the Virgin Islands, VIERS has served as a remote field station and marine laboratory since the end of the Tektite projects. The current opportunity, "VIERS the next 50 years: rebuilding resilient research infrastructure at the Virgin Island Environmental Resource Station,” initially focused on building housing for visiting researchers following the destruction of the historic campgrounds by hurricanes Irma and Maria in 2017. The focus of this project changed to the restoration of the laboratory building when it became apparent that without improvements, the laboratory would no longer function safely as a remote facility. In addition, the researchers grew accustomed to using more comfortable short-term rentals in St John, and the Park Service delayed approval of the designed housing units at VIERS, causing higher costs than initially projected. 

The improvements increased the covered work areas by more than 500 sqft, replaced the damaged seawater pumping system for experimental mesocosm experiments, and added 3500 Watts of solar panels with battery and inverter to provide power during frequent power outages. Other improvements included repairing cracked and damaged plastering, replacing damaged storm doors and windows, resurfacing the floors, and repainting the buildings, a new SCUBA compressor and repairs to the bathroom, septic system, shower, freshwater filtering system, and equipment storage units. Air conditioning was installed in two rooms to allow researchers to work in climate-controlled areas during the heat of the summer.   These critical improvements will keep the VIERS laboratory functional for many years and continue the valuable work done at the remote field station.

This work includes more than fifty peer-reviewed research papers published in the past five years on the work done at VIERS. These improvements will allow this work to continue for several decades. The completion of this work and the relevance of VIERS was reported in the local newspaper, https://stthomassource.com/content/2024/11/17/renovations-completed-at-viers-lab-signal-a-milestone-in-rebuilding-efforts/. We look forward to the National Park, with the help of local and national donors, rebuilding the campground.  However, the research can now continue at the VIERS laboratory due to the investment by the National Science Foundation.
